title: Forex reserves decline by over $1 bn at $353 bn
text: Forex reserves decline by over $1 bn at $353 bn Rupee breaches 64 again, falls near 2-month low RBI foreign exchange reserves fell by over $1 billion for the week ending July 17 to $353.33 billion, shows data released on Friday The Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) foreign exchange reserves fell by over $1 billion for the week ending July 17 to $353.33 billion, shows data released on Friday. The foreign exchange reserves are currently at a level last seen in the week ending June 5 at $352.71 billion. Foreign currency assets, a key component of foreign exchange reserves, fell by $982.14 million to $328.93 billion. During the week gold reserves remained unchanged at $19.07 billion. For the week under review, the Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) fell by $39.6 million to $4.02 billion, while India's reserve position with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) stood at $1.30 billion recording a fall of $12.8 million. On Friday, the rupee weakened near two-month low. The rupee had opened at 63.97 and during intra-day trades it touched a low of 63.88 before closing at 64.04 per dollar. On a weekly basis, according to Bloomberg the rupee weakened 0.9% from July 17, the most since the five days ended April 24, to 64.0425 a dollar. The rupee had ended at 64.12 per dollar on May 27 this year. ALSO READ: Forex reserves rise to $352.71 billion “Today there was huge demand fro dollars from corporates as well as oil companies which led to weakening of the rupee. Though the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) had intervened, but in a limited way. Even going forward the rupee is biased towards weakening next week,” said Sandeep Gonsalves, forex consultant and dealer, Mecklai & Mecklai. Currency dealers believe that next week month-end dollar demand by importers will be more due to which the rupee can even touch around 64.25 per dollar level.
